Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 10:18AM tonihicks1 wrote: What is your injection?  I forget the name of one of mine (ugh! - I will resend later - how can I forget the name??) but the other one I get is Exigen which I believe is for mets to the bone.  The one I cannot remember is the one that pushed me into menopause.  Then I moved on to anastrole orally - which is just like tamoxiphen but for me, a lot worse hot flashes.  I switched over from celexa for depression and anxiety to effexor for depression and anxiety and boom - no more hot flashes.  So let us know how you do.  Lots of ideas for making these therapies workable. Take care!
Posts.Title: New to the Stage IV Forum SusaninSF MameMe

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2014 08:56PM tonihicks1 wrote: Wow - that is a lot to learn of at one time.  I will tell you though, this is a great group to talk to. Just to know that one other person is feeling the same way you do or taking the same med or experiencing the same type of mets.  It just makes it all seem like you are not alone. I really liked what one of the ladies in this forum said about "Dr. Google"  That crap will make you crazy!  One of my dear friends is a nurse in a breast cancer center and that is the first advice she gave me.  But one day, I got sucked into searching and boy was I sorry.  You can find your worst nightmare out there.  Stay connected with this group and chart your own course.  You will do great!  Sending you big hugs and prayers!
Posts.Title: New to the Stage IV Forum SusaninSF MameMe

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 05:31AM tonihicks1 wrote: I am Stage IV mets to bone (left hip bone) and lungs.  dx 1/20/12.
Posts.Title: How Many Are We? DivineMrsM kt1966

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2014 07:11PM tonihicks1 wrote: I was 46 when I was diagnosed.   I have no history of ANY cancer in my family.  I got mammograms at 40, 41, 42, 43, then missed 44 and 45 and boy am I sorry!  I would NEVER let my daughter go without having a regular mamoogram, whether I am BRAC or not.  My personal experience (now I am 53 and Stage IV!) says that it is not consistent with the message of catching BC early.
Posts.Title: Poll - How old were you when dx with BC Times3 Minetta57

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2014 06:51PM tonihicks1 wrote: I have been on Xgeva for 2 years.  No constipation.  I have had stiffness which I have heard is a side effect.  A good reason to get on a walking program to keep yourself loose.  Walking along with Miralax and water may also help with the constipation.  Other than that - no side effects and a reduction in the size of the lesion on my left hip bone.  No other lesions in my bones.  I do have lesions in my lungs but that is not what Xgeva is for.  I heard the same from my onc as TarheelMichelle.  They do not really know if it is effective - it can't hurt and sometimes it helps.  I think you should get used to that sort of dx. There are not many definitives in this world of treatment.  Its all about containing and shrinking the cancer while keeping you feeling good.  I think Xgeva has been great in that regard!
Posts.Title: Xgeva for Bone Mets: Time on? Results? SEs? WanderingSpirit WanderingSpirit

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2014 05:30PM tonihicks1 wrote: You know, now that you say it, I think I have alternated!  Gosh - shame on me for sharing incorrect information!  The woman who gives me the injection usually has me laughing so hard that its hard to remember.  She is hilarious!  I am also a bruiser and bleeder!
Posts.Title: stage 4 zoladex users smiley2 Redheadfriendship

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2014 05:04PM tonihicks1 wrote: I get this every month and the needle is HUGE!  It is like a stapler injecting the end of a pencil lead into your belly.  I also get it just below and left of my belly button.  I always get it in a fatty section.  I do not get lidocaine, not because I am brave but because I was never offered anything but an ice pack.  So I just skipped it.  I do not get any lymphedema from it.  In fact, I have not noticed any se.  Hang in there.
